instances.location: /player/legal [name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter]
instances.issueDetail:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. The payloads 21800829' or 8606=8606-- and 57894777' or 6230=6235-- were each submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter. These two requests resulted in different responses, indicating that the input is being incorporated into a SQL query in an unsafe way.

Note that automated difference-based tests for SQL injection flaws can often be unreliable and are prone to false positive results. You should manually review the reported requests and responses to confirm whether a vulnerability is actually present.

instances.location: /player/message [name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter]
instances.issueDetail:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. The payload (select*from(select(sleep(20)))a) was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected SQL command caused a time delay.

The database appears to be MySQL.

instances.location: /login [name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter]
instances.issueDetail:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. The payload (select*from(select(sleep(20)))a) was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected SQL command caused a time delay.

The database appears to be MySQL.

The X-Mapping-mamhcfmd cookie appears to be vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. The payload ,(select*from(select(sleep(20)))a) was submitted in the X-Mapping-mamhcfmd cookie. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected SQL command caused a time delay.

The database appears to be MySQL.

The request appears to be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks against authenticated users.

The original request contains parameters that look like they may be anti-CSRF tokens. However the request is successful if these parameters are removed.
The request appears to be vulnerable to cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks against authenticated users.

The value of the Dober.games_PlayCard cookie is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload yjgknr5eww>< was submitted in the Dober.games_PlayCard cookie. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This behavior demonstrates that it is possible to inject new HTML tags into the returned document. An attempt was made to identify a full proof-of-concept attack for injecting arbitrary JavaScript but this was not successful. You should manually examine the application's behavior and attempt to identify any unusual input validation or other obstacles that may be in place.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a cookie, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. Typically, you will need to find a means of setting an arbitrary cookie value in the victim's browser in order to exploit the vulnerability. Applications often contain "cookie-forcing" conditions which make this possible, and such a condition in any related domain or subdomain can potentially be used for this purpose. Nonetheless, this limitation somewhat mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

Nonetheless, this limitation somewhat mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

The value of the Dober.games_PlayCard cookie is copied into the HTML document as plain text between tags. The payload vpzch51u1g>< was submitted in the Dober.games_PlayCard cookie. This input was echoed unmodified in the application's response.

This behavior demonstrates that it is possible to inject new HTML tags into the returned document. An attempt was made to identify a full proof-of-concept attack for injecting arbitrary JavaScript but this was not successful. You should manually examine the application's behavior and attempt to identify any unusual input validation or other obstacles that may be in place.

Because the user data that is copied into the response is submitted within a cookie, the application's behavior is not trivial to exploit in an attack against another user. Typically, you will need to find a means of setting an arbitrary cookie value in the victim's browser in order to exploit the vulnerability. Applications often contain "cookie-forcing" conditions which make this possible, and such a condition in any related domain or subdomain can potentially be used for this purpose. Nonetheless, this limitation somewhat mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

The value of the order request parameter is copied into the value of an HTML tag attribute which is encapsulated in double quotation marks. The payload "><%EscQo> was submitted in the order parameter. This input was echoed as "><%escqo> in the application's response.

This behavior demonstrates that it is possible to inject new HTML tags into the returned document. An attempt was made to identify a full proof-of-concept attack for injecting arbitrary JavaScript but this was not successful. You should manually examine the application's behavior and attempt to identify any unusual input validation or other obstacles that may be in place.

The application appears to be blocking common XSS attacks, but this defense was bypassed by submitting an unexpected character following the opening tag bracket. Some browsers, notably Internet Explorer 9, will tolerate the unexpected character, allowing the attack to succeed. This bypass indicates that the application may be using .NET Request Validation, or may be using a simple regex-based filter to block some bad inputs.

Note that a redirection occurred between the attack request and the response containing the echoed input. It is necessary to follow this redirection for the attack to succeed. When the attack is carried out via a browser, the redirection will be followed automatically.

Nonetheless, this limitation somewhat mitigates the impact of the vulnerability.

Some browsers, notably Internet Explorer 9, will tolerate the unexpected character, allowing the attack to succeed. This bypass indicates that the application may be using .NET Request Validation, or may be using a simple regex-based filter to block some bad inputs.

instances.location: /login [name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter]
instances.issueDetail:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to Python code injection attacks. The submitted value appears to be placed into a dynamically evaluated Python statement, within an unquoted context.

The payload eval(compile('for x in range(1):\n import time\n time.sleep(20)','a','single')) was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected Python code caused a time delay.

instances.location: /player/message [name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter]
instances.issueDetail:
The name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter appears to be vulnerable to Python code injection attacks. The submitted value appears to be placed into a dynamically evaluated Python statement, within an unquoted context.

The payload eval(compile('for x in range(1):\n import time\n time.sleep(20)','a','single')) was submitted in the name of an arbitrarily supplied URL parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected Python code caused a time delay.

The returnurl parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands. The command output does not appear to be returned in the application's responses, however it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the returnurl parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

The order parameter appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands. The command output does not appear to be returned in the application's responses, however it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the order parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

The X-Mapping-mamhcfmd cookie appears to be vulnerable to OS command injection attacks. It is possible to use various shell metacharacters to inject arbitrary OS commands. The command output does not appear to be returned in the application's responses, however it is possible to inject time delay commands to verify the existence of the vulnerability.

The payload |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #' |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1||`ping -c 21 127.0.0.1` #\" |ping -n 21 127.0.0.1 was submitted in the X-Mapping-mamhcfmd cookie. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected command caused a time delay.

The returnurl parameter appears to be vulnerable to Ruby code injection attacks. The submitted value appears to be placed into a dynamically evaluated Ruby statement, within a single-quoted context.

The payload '+sleep(20.to_i)+' was submitted in the returnurl parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected Ruby code caused a time delay.

The order parameter appears to be vulnerable to Ruby code injection attacks. The submitted value appears to be placed into a dynamically evaluated Ruby statement, within a single-quoted context.

The payload '+sleep(20.to_i)+' was submitted in the order parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected Ruby code caused a time delay.

The bFromHelpPage parameter appears to be vulnerable to Ruby code injection attacks. The submitted value appears to be placed into a dynamically evaluated Ruby statement, within a single-quoted context.

The payload '+sleep(20.to_i)+' was submitted in the bFromHelpPage parameter. The application timed out when responding to the request, indicating that the injected Ruby code caused a time delay.

issues.name: TLS cookie without secure flag set

instances.issueDetail:
The following cookies were issued by the application and do not have the secure flag set:
  • ASP.NET_SessionId
  • X-Mapping-mamhcfmd
The highlighted cookie appears to contain a session token, which may increase the risk associated with this issue. You should review the contents of the cookies to determine their function.

The following cookie was issued by the application and does not have the secure flag set:
  • ASP.NET_SessionId
The cookie appears to contain a session token, which may increase the risk associated with this issue. You should review the contents of the cookie to determine its function.

The following cookie was issued by the application and does not have the secure flag set:
  • __RequestVerificationToken_Lw__
The cookie appears to contain a session token, which may increase the risk associated with this issue. You should review the contents of the cookie to determine its function.This issue was found in multiple locations under the reported path.
